summary: the PEDV genome (28 kb) consists of seven open reading frames (ORFs) (2). the 5′ two-thirds of the genome contains the replicase-transcriptase ORF1 (overlapping ORF1a and ORF1b), followed by five ORFs encoding four structural proteins and one strain-specific accessory protein. PEDV was first reported in the early 1970s as the causative agent of PED. porcine enteric coronaviruses infect villous enterocytes, causing atrophic enteritis that leads to malabsorptive diarrhea (7, 8, 18) enteric coronaviruses primarily infect villous enterocytes, causing atrophic enteritis. fluorescent microbead-based immunoassay (FMIA) and whole-virus enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) the final aim of this project was to identify highly sensitive and specific PEDV antigen targets for the antibody-based differential diagnosis of coronavirus-related enteric disease. inoculation % homology for amino acid sequence of PEDV recombinant polypeptides S1, N, M, and E. five recombinant polypeptides derived from the four PEDV structural proteins (S, M, N, and E) and a WV antigen were generated. proteins S and M were truncated on the basis of gene size, hydrophobicity, and antigenic features. the most abundant protein in the virion envelope (35), the N protein is the most abundant coronavirus antigen produced throughout infection (36), and the S protein forms the crown-like projection of the viral surface (37). the lower response in the FMIA assay can be attributed to the fact that the Luminex carboxylated magnetic microbeads bind WV (intact) PEDV particles less efficiently than they bind proteins or polypeptides with free amino groups. pigs exposed to different coronaviruses that share genetic and antigenic traits that may contribute to false-positive results. recent evidence suggesting antibody cross-reactivity between PEDV and TGEV (13) and between PEDV and PDCoV (40) raised concerns about the specificity of PEDV serologic testing using assays based on targets containing the most conserved regions. further analysis identified at least one epitope on the N-terminal region of the PEDV/TGEV N protein that contributed to this cross-reactivity (13). cross-reactivity could be corrected by increasing the S/P ratio cutoff value from 0.59 to 0.80, but this would reduce the diagnostic sensitivity from 83.3% to 76.3%. pigs' serum samples were tested with a PEDV immunofluorescence assay (21), PEDV WV ELISA (24), TGEV/PRCV differential ratio as follows: S / P ratio = ( sample FI background mean FI) seven-week-old pigs (n = 72) were purchased from a conventional wean-to-finish farm with no history of porcine coronavirus infections. the pigs were prescreened for evidence of infection with PEDV, TGEV, PRCV, and PDCoV. pig fecal and nasal swabs were tested by a PEDV immunofluorescence assay (21), PEDV WV ELISA (24), TGEV/PRCV min at 4°C. the soluble expression of a histidine (His) tag-fused N-PEDV protein (50.4 kDa) was confirmed by SDS-PAGE analysis. gene was amplified using forward primer 5′-CAT CAT CAT CAT CAT CAT ATG PCR products were cloned, sequenced, and transformed into BL21(DE3) cells as described above for the N protein. rS1 non-S-INDEL (0.6 mg/ml; bead region 53), rS1 S-INDEL (0.3 mg/ml; bead region 45), rN (0.44 mg/ml; bead region 64), rM (1 mg/ml; bead region 12), and 60 l of purified WV antigen were coupled to 5 106 carboxylated magnetic microspheres. each set of coupled beads was individually evaluated using different 50 l streptavidin phycoerythrin (SAPE; Moss Inc., Pasadena, MD, USA) at a dilution in assay buffer was added to each well, followed by a 30-min incubation. the microspheres were resuspended in 100 l of assay buffer and analyzed using a dual-laser bio-Plex 200 instrument. Pearson's chi-square test was used to detect differences in the number of seropositive animals over time (by DPI) among the individual antigens. one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with Tukey's correction was used for multiple comparisons.
